body: will do
@DaanHoogland You can merge it I think

Code-wise I'm not to happy. There are all kinds of assumptions about paths. mkisofs for example always being there in /usr/bin.

Using /tmp for temporary directories, who says that /tmp is big enough on every system? Always using /var/lib/libvirt to place the ISO? Why not fetch the local storage pool and figure out what the path is.

It's not guaranteerd that it will be /var/lib/libvirt/images on all systems.

Imho there are to many assumptions in the code which makes it fragile.

[cloudstack-pull-analysis #23](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-analysis/23/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

-1 - this break upgrade-ability for really old cloudstack installations. There is no _necessity_ to remove the code, you can choose to ignore coverity and other static analysis issues instead of breaking upgrade paths for really old installations.

Currently, I'm aware of few large cloudstack installations who are going to upgrade from 3.0.x (you might have even noticed a recent fix I made to allow one of such upgrades from 3.0.x to 4.5.x) to 4.5.x or 4.6.x

[cloudstack-pull-rats #91](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-rats/91/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

I am not sure how severe are the coverity reported issues. If there are customers who may want to upgrade then it is better to wait before deprecating this code. Also if we know of such old cloudstack deployment maybe we can mail them to upgrade or loose the upgrade path.
But till then it will be better if we let this code hang around.

[cloudstack-pull-requests #789](https://builds.apache.org/job/cloudstack-pull-requests/789/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

-1 @DaanHoogland what is the reasoning for removing the old upgrade code (please amend the commit to explain the reasoning for posterity)?  As far as I know, we don't have a policy regarding how far back we support upgrades.  Minimally, this commit should include a documentation update that explains how far back upgrades are supported, and the steps required for older users to get up-to-date (e.g. a multi-step upgrade).

@koushik-das 'dead local storage' is a source analysis term for 'unused variable'. Not severe unless it happens a lot, because of memory consumption.
